content.title: Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis) - Vascular Implications
content.summary: Large vessel vasculitis predominantly affecting elderly patients, involving cranial arteries and the aorta, with risk of vision loss and aortic aneurysm formation.

definitions.definition: Systemic granulomatous vasculitis affecting large and medium arteries, typically in patients over 50, characterized by giant cells and granulomatous inflammation in the vessel wall.
GCA phenotype predominantly affecting cranial arteries (temporal, ophthalmic, posterior ciliary), presenting with headache, jaw claudication, and visual symptoms.
GCA phenotype involving the aorta and its major branches, presenting with limb claudication, aortic aneurysm, and systemic inflammation.

key_concepts.explanation: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) is the most feared complication. Central retinal artery occlusion also occurs. Vision loss is often sudden and irreversible - emergency high-dose steroids are essential.
Large vessel GCA causes aortitis leading to aneurysm (thoracic > abdominal). Risk of aortic aneurysm is 17x higher than general population. Annual imaging surveillance is recommended.

ESR typically >50mm/hr, CRP elevated. Temporal artery biopsy is gold standard (≥1cm length, examine multiple sections). Ultrasound 'halo sign' has high specificity. PET-CT detects large vessel involvement.
High-dose steroids (1mg/kg prednisone) initiated immediately if vision threatened. Tocilizumab (IL-6 inhibitor) is steroid-sparing. Lifelong aortic surveillance is recommended.

evidence.citation: GiACTA Trial, Stone et al., NEJM, 2017
evidence.finding: Tocilizumab plus prednisone achieved sustained remission in 56% vs 14% with prednisone alone, with significant steroid sparing
Patients with GCA have 17-fold increased risk of thoracic aortic aneurysm and 2.4-fold increased risk of AAA

clinical_pearls: Never delay steroids for biopsy - biopsy can be done up to 2 weeks after starting treatment
Bilateral temporal artery biopsy increases diagnostic yield by 10-15%
Jaw claudication is highly specific for GCA (specificity 94%)
GCA and polymyalgia rheumatica overlap in 40-60% of patients
Aortic surveillance should continue even after GCA is in remission
learning_objectives: Distinguish cranial from large vessel GCA phenotypes
Recognize ophthalmic emergencies requiring immediate treatment
Describe the role of temporal artery biopsy and ultrasound in diagnosis
State the evidence for tocilizumab as steroid-sparing therapy
